Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Cultural Dimensions of Ebola Virus Transmission in Guinea, West Africa

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Historically, outbreaks of Ebola Virus in human populations have been linked to exposure to infected wildlife and generally limited to isolated rural areas in East Africa. In contrast, the current Ebola Virus outbreak in West Africa, which began in December 2013, has evolved into a more complex, larger, and multi-country epidemic. Furthermore, international travel and medical relief efforts have brought a few cases of Ebola Virus infection to both the United States and Europe. In the past, social scientists have found that to be effective, disease control efforts must be grounded in understanding local cultural beliefs because they underlie indigenous medical practice and influence comprehension of public health education messages. Given these earlier findings, the recent spread of Ebola Virus disease suggests the need for more attention to the social and cultural dimensions of disease transmission. The research funded by this award responds to this need. Results will provide critical practical information for current health education efforts, contribute to improved disease transmission theory, and also help the United States prepare for future global epidemics of infectious diseases. Informed by Cultural Dimensions of Disease Causation Theory, this research bridges cultural anthropology, biomedical anthropology, and epidemiological outbreak response practices aligned with Western medicine.

Dr. Sally Lahm and Dr. Amira Roess, both of Georgetown University, will survey and interview a sample of residents and health care workers in 72 selected communities throughout Guinea, the origin country of the current epidemic. Dr. Lahm's previous research, during four Ebola Virus epidemics in another part of Africa, found that the effectiveness of emergency public health education and social mobilization efforts was determined in part by local theories of disease causation, socioeconomic and political factors, traditional subsistence and foraging practices, and religion. The researchers will test the theory that the same is true in Guinea and may account in part for the persistence of the current epidemic. Findings will help scientists who seek to integrate cultural and bio-medical disease models of disease transmission. The international research team will collect data on health education and social mobilization activities, Ebola Virus knowledge, medical practices, communication and transport systems, and health care seeking behavior. In addition, the project will provide preliminary data on the distinct meanings of disease, illness experience, and health from the viewpoint of several regional ethnic groups in Guinea; the effects of gender on these perceptions; and how local people understand Ebola as a phenomenon. Because of regional cultural continuities, results will apply to areas beyond Guinea where Ebola virus and other zoonotic infectious diseases are known to occur. To maximize broader impacts, the project research will support the development of an online, open-source map of Ebola response in study villages; the development of a teaching module on the use of anthropological theory for designing health education campaigns and for integration into primary and secondary school classrooms in Africa and elsewhere; and the provision of policy recommendations to improve public health education campaigns through integration of anthropological research in West Africa, connecting government, non-governmental, international and domestic actors.

This proposal was submitted in response to the NSF 15-006 Dear Colleague Letter (DCL) on the Ebola Virus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studies of the underlying cultural models of health and disease related to both local ethno-medicines and Western biomedicine in the context of emerging zoonotic infectious diseases are largely absent from the anthropological scholarship, especially in West Africa. Ethno-medical classifications in many parts of the world, including the study area in Guinea, encompass naturalistic (related to mechanisms of contagion and pollution) and personalistic (spiritual and supernatural malevolence) causes that are at times fundamentally at odds with concepts of western medicine. Informed by the Theory of Cultural Dimensions of Disease Causation, this research contributed to the knowledge base of cultural and medical anthropology in Guinea, especially of how risk perception affects illness prevention and how illness representations affect community response to epidemics, particularly in the socio-political context of Guinea, with significance for other African countries. The project advanced understanding of how culture influences beliefs about disease, treatment and health practices and how public health messaging is interpreted in the context of zoonotic infectious disease outbreaks.

 

The objective of this research was to determine the influence of culture, religion, and personal perceptions in regard to the Ebola Virus epidemic and Ebola as a phenomenon. The study was conducted with elders, leaders, and households in 42 villages comprised of 24 ethnic groups across Guinea. The results revealed that the large majority of the participants do not understand basic concepts about the Ebola Virus and what measures to take in the presence of potentially infected wildlife and humans, despite an intensive nationwide public health campaign. Naturalistic (wind, water, insects, and miasma theory) and religious interpretations (destiny or punishment from God) were prevalently named as causes of Ebola. This and the fact that the last cases of Ebola Virus in Guinea were linked to a person in the capital who sought care from several traditional medical practitioners show that culturally-based concepts of illness causation and disease classification are strongly rooted in indigenous belief systems in both urban and rural areas of Guinea. In parallel, the majority of the village health care personnel interviewed were unsure of some key concepts about the Ebola Virus and they felt unprepared to treat or interact with Ebola patients, despite specific training. Many Ebola-related terms used by villagers appeared to be culture-based and combined with those of western medicine, perhaps to make the best sense of the epidemic. Cultural health attributions affect beliefs about disease, treatment and health practices. To have effective interventions, it is important to understand how people define and interpret contagious diseases.

The findings from this research are critical to efforts aimed at improving and informing the content of curricula for anthropology and medicine and training courses for health care personnel, as well as community health education and social mobilization programs in Guinea. The project provided opportunities for Guinean specialists in sociology and community health medicine to conduct collaborative research during the largest Ebola Virus epidemic in history. This study has direct implications for policymakers, social scientists, and NGOs engaged in health education and response to outbreaks of Ebola and other emerging zoonotic infectious diseases. A detailed technical report on the major findings of the project was sent to the Director of the Commission for Research on Ebola of the Ministry of Health and Public Hygiene of Guinea. Electronic and printed versions of the report were given to the Minister of Health and Public Hygiene.
